Like it always is when you arrive at a foreign land's airport (especially after a 14 hour flight), I was terribly disoriented when I arrived atLondon Heathrow. When I got out the gates, I just followed the crowd and was quite surprised to find out that immigration comes first before baggage claim; usually you get your bags first before immigration check right? Anyway, so I shuffled through my bag for my passport -- keeping in mind, that it's my US passport that I should present, not the Phil one -- and flashed a big smile to the immigration officer as I handed it to him. As he looked at it, and at me, all I could think of was, "Dont quarantine me!!! For God's sake, do NOT quarantine me!!!" Thankfully, this was the conversation that ensued:
 
Immigration guy: Are you here for business or holiday?
Me: Holiday. For 10 days.
IG: Are you seeing anybody here?
Me: Yes, my mother.
IG: Does she live here?
Me: No. She's here on business and I'm tagging along. But I'm going all around, while she stays in London for the entire duration.
IG: Uh huh. Are you still a student, are you working, or are you looking for work?
Me: (thinking, ulol mo gago, feeling mo mag TNT ako dito. asa pa) Oh I'm still a student. I'm just on vacation
IG: And where are you going after your 10 days here? Going back to the USA?
Me: Yes.
 
Yahoo. Cleared. 
 
After I claimed my bags, and exited the carousel area, I heard my mother before I saw her. She was shouting "Mia! Mia! Over here!" Okaaay kakahiya hahaha. Then we were in conjunction being disoriented. There were so many signs, pointing at so many directions. But at least we knew where we wanted to go (pays off to research before leaving hay salamat). We needed to get to the platform for theHeathrow express which will take us from Terminal 4 to Terminal 2 where the bus station is, where the bus will take us to our hotel. It was a long zigzag filled walk, and we exerted effort keeping left, instead of keeping right (baliktad dito twinks eh. you walk on the left, cars drive on the left, driver's seat on the right). Finally got to the hotel shortly before midnight.
 
The next day, June 15, I was off to Newcastle.
 
I was super OC about the trains schedules before I left Manila, that I had them printed out and organized in a file. It paid off as I catched the 7:47am train to Newcastle, with a change at Birmingham.  What I failed to do was to reserve seats. I didn't bother assuming there would always be seats. But fuck, there weren't any seats. You've got to hand it to the British train system. Super ayos. You get in the train and vacant seats you cant sit on coz a computerized marquee floats above the seat labeling it such as "Reserved from York to Durnham" or "Seat is not reserved." Since I didn't have any seat reserved, I had to stand for a bit till someone left, and sat at the "Reserved from York to Durnham" seat until the train stopped at York. At York, I had to vacate it coz the reserved person got it, while I searched for another seat not reserved and occupied at the moment. Super squatter moment haha. I changed seats about 5 times till Newcastle.
 
After almost 4 hours, I finally arrived at Newcastle. My hostel, Albatross Backpackers Inn, was a short walk from the train station. When I got to my room, one of my roommates was already there (the room was good for 4 people; 2 bunk beds). Her name was Estel and was from Quebec (Twinks yun yung French part ng Canada. Dun yung setting ng Whole Nine Yards starring Bruce Willis and Matthew Perry ata yun). Estel is 27 years old, graduated HRM, and currently works as the front desk girl of a hotel in Quebec. She still lives with her parents, got bored with work, and took a 50-day leave so she could go around the UK. 
 
Anyway after saying hi hello, I had to leave coz I had to catch my 330pm appointment at the Newcastle University for the campus tour.  I went there and met Victor, the guy who was assigned to tour me. The tour was okay.  The school reminded me of Ateneo; most of its buildings were red bricked parang SEC.  Walang kwenta tong si Victor (who works for the university's International Office) coz he doesnt know where the school of management is hahaha. So we just toured the parts he knew (which thankfully included the important buildings) and I listened to his stories (student life, cost of living, his life story, etc.) He was a double major -- English and Film -- and after having graduated, still didn't know what to do in life, so he worked for the university. He's 32 years old now, and still doesn't know what the fuck to do hahaha. He wants to learn Japanese, though, and aspires to go to Kyoto and work there. Because of his interests, I had an in depth tour of the Department of Languages...and the library.
 
Our tour finished shortly before 4pm and he invited me for coffee. He had a scheduled Japanese language session with his tutor who was a post grad student there, and wanted me to meet her. Winner. Super laughtrip. The Japanese girl (who was pretty Twinks..kamukha nung crush nating girl sa Boston Legal, remember?) was teaching Victor basic Japanese -- as in hi hello how are you how do i get to blah blah -- and Victor was helping her with her English. Sobrang lugi ni Victor coz while she taught him basic, conversational stuff, she was asking him the meanings of words like "pedagogical" and "epistemology" hahaha "what does epistemology mean? (then Victor would explain) then "oh I see...so when you say epistemological, what exactly does that imply?" hahahahaha goodluck kay Victor gago. After about 30 minutes, I excused myself and left.  Then I roamed around Newcastle.
 

Uneventful roaming around of Newcastle. Cool thing was that the sun was still up at 9pm. The day is long so you could do a lot. Not a cool thing was it was absolutely prohibited to smoke in the pubs. What the fuck. Whats the point of drinking if you cant smoke at the same time. Burat ako so I didnt drink haha. Went back to the hostel before 11.

Am I my brother’s keeper?
- Cain


    I have two younger brothers. The one next to me, Yori, and I are very close.  He is the typical middle child who is very vulnerable, plays it safe, and resigns to follow the footsteps of the older sibling (me).  He shares with me pretty much everything that happens in his life, and he consults with me regarding pretty much every decision he makes.  I’m glad to be the in the receiving end of such admiration and trust, and I try very hard to be a dutiful older sister and not to screw up. 
    
I am very happy about our relationship, and at the same time, I am scared and pressured to do things right because I know he is always watching me closely, waiting for the opportunity to imitate my actions.  Needless to say, I have a very strong influence on him, and even a small comment I give him sticks to his mind like a commandment he will always remember and live by.
Conversely, I also learn from him specially when I’m angry about something and my judgment is clouded, and I lean to him for help.

My youngest brother, Gino, and I, on the other hand, are not that close.  He is also the typical youngest sibling that tries so hard to be different and deviates from the norm most of the time.  Because of our differences in attitudes and perspective on things, we often clash and argue with me always winning of course.

But despite our differences and how I feel like killing him most of the time, I am nonetheless there for him in his times of need, and he is also there when I need him, too.  When I need a different opinion, I don’t go to Yori because I know he’ll just agree with me, I instead go to Gino.  So I guess our relationship is healthy as well in the sense that even though our opinions clash most of the time, the communication remains alive.  I have no doubts that in the future, when he gets older, more mature, and less irritable, we would also be the best of friends.

Sooner or later, we all quote our mothers.
- Bern Williams
            
One father is more than a thousand schoolmasters.
- George Herbert


My father is the luckiest man alive.  This is because in his 63 years (and counting) here on earth, he never had a real job.  “Do good, and the world will take care of you,” he said.  This isn’t exactly true because the person doing most of the caring for him is my mother.  When I look at them as a couple, however, I think that it is for the betterment of their relationship that my dad is how my dad is.  This is because my mom has a very strong personality, and subconsciously wants to control everything she can.  Family trips are planned to the letter, with an itinerary made on an excel worksheet complete with date, time, place, and agenda in the place we are to go to.  So if in the unlikely case that my dad steps up to fulfill the metaphorical role of being breadwinner/boss, they would clash, and our united and peaceful family as I know it would go asunder.  

My father and I  do not have a close relationship.  We rarely talk with each other, and during the few times that we do, it would just be him asking me to do an errand, or me asking him a trivia question.  I don’t mean to make this sound bad, but his role as a dad to me has been reduced to being a data bank.  Because he was rigorously trained in the seminary, he is omniscient to certain degree; since I was very young, and until now that I am not a student anymore, he never failed to answer correctly every question I asked him for a school assignment (except math and science) or a task I’d be doing for work.  I guess the reason for this kind of relationship is that he’s rarely around the house, and when he is, he doesn’t exert effort to really converse.  As an effect, I don’t notice his presence when he’s home, or his absence when he’s not. 

    Another thing about my dad is that I know he has made many, many mistakes in his life, but I don’t judge him for that.  He isn’t the breadwinner of our family when he’s supposed to (my mom is), because of him I have a number of half-siblings, and he isn’t exactly the role model a father should be for many reasons.  But weirdly, I don’t harbor any angry feelings towards him.   I don’t know why.  Maybe its because that no matter how grave the mistakes he has done and will do, no matter how much he could screw up, he is still a good person who really, really likes to help people, and also, he will always be my father.

    My mother and I, on the other hand, are very close.  She is a great role model, ever supportive of what ever I do, and ever so lenient.  Also, she always tries to correct my flaws, and when she does so, I see it like a television commercial: you’ve heard it a million times, you know what is coming, but you listen anyway.  For one thing, she always criticizes my driving; she says I don’t drive fast enough and that I press on the brakes too suddenly.  For other thing, she always sends me on money errands to improve my financial literacy; I go to the city halls to pay taxes, which I really, really dread (government offices suck), and I go to the banks to invest money in equities, UITFs, time deposits, etc., and even my allowance when I was still a student was given on a monthly basis like a salary which was also deposited into an ATM account.  Also, she always tells me not to trust anyone so easily and that I should stop giving money to street children because I’m not really helping that way.

    She criticizes everything about me from my laziness, to my addiction to TV series which I buy on pirated DVDs and which I could watch all day long, to my cluttered room, to my dusty laptop, to my gas and Starbucks expenses, to my coming home very late, to my ugly handwriting, to my inefficient time management (cramming)…I swear the list is endless.  But despite everything, we are extremely close maybe because I never receive her criticisms quietly; I answer back, and criticize her too!  Communication between us is open, honest, and free flowing, and I think that’s a good thing.

    Talking with my mom is just like talking to a friend in the sense that there is no censorship in the exchange of words, and the conversation is filled with candor. With my mom, emotions are reported when experienced, and it is never to imply judgment.  Candor does not connote disrespect.  Rather, it implies the depth in the relationship where one person is so comfortable with the other, that he/she is confident that the other won’t take any offense.  I think this manifests honesty, authenticity, and maturity between persons and therefore, I am confident in saying that my relationship with my mom is nothing short of healthy.

    Now that I am already working, my mom has backed off a bit on the nagging and the criticisms.  I welcome this change because it signifies trust from her on a different level; she’s now letting me fly on my own wings without much guidance.  But sometimes, like when I’m driving and I put on a sudden stop, I hear my mom’s voice in my mind, and I know exactly what she would have been saying, and this makes me smile.

It was for economical and sightseeing reasons that we embarked on a land trip to Leyte.  The airfare for the 5 members of our family seemed unreasonable, and knowing that the route from Manila to Leyte was scenic, we began the long drive on the 23rd of December, projecting to arrive at our ancestral home in time for Christmas Eve.  Being a person who has had myriad opportunities to travel abroad, I never thought our own country has places that could be at par with what I have seen in America and Europe.  Alas, I was mistaken.  As we passed through Bicol, the Ateneo de Naga Campus, for example, reminded me of Yale, and their life sized, Filipino themed rendition of the nativity could compare to the statues in Rome.  The Daraga Church, found on top of a hill, with the magnificent view of Legaspi City that it offers makes one recall the Sacre Cour Basilica in Paris.  The Cagsawa Ruins in Legaspi leaves one awestruck with a sense of history and melancholy – somehow like the feeling one gets amid the ruins in Greece.  After seeing all these sights, we spent the night, at the marvelous Home of the Clergy in Sorsogon – commented on by both local and foreign priests to be one of the most beautiful clergy residences around the world – where my Dad’s friend, the Bishop, resides.  We slept peacefully, happy and content, not knowing what perils we would experience the next day.

    On the 24th of December, at 6am, we boarded the roro that would take us and our van from Sorsogon to Samar.  The hour-long trip on the boat was a worthy experience in itself as it was my first time to see so many cars and buses cramped together at the bottom of a boat, while the passengers withstood the tremendously bumpy ride, struggling to find a comfortable spot upstairs.  We arrived in Allen, Northern Samar, at around 7am, and after breakfast, began the 9-hour drive to our town, Tanauan, Leyte.  The roads of Samar, are by far, the worst of the worst that I’ve seen across the globe.  They are bereft of cement or asphalt, and there are more potholes than flat surfaces; it did not help that the heavy rains that day covered the potholes with water, rendering it impossible for my dad to ascertain if the holes were deep or shallow.  After about 40 minutes of driving, we found ourselves passing through a pothole so deep that our heads hit the ceiling of our van because of the impact.  Seconds later, the alarm for “low on oil” sounded, at first slowly, then suddenly rapidly, and soon enough, our van stalled – engine oil was on “empty.”  The impact from the pothole cracked open the crank case of our van (where engine oil is stored), and since it is made of aluminum, mechanics could not give it a quick fix; it was irreparable they said, we had to replace the part.
  
  We ended up spending 9 hours of the day before Christmas, stranded in the middle of nowhere, and since the entire family subscribed to the same cell phone service provider that had no signal in that area, we were isolated.  Later, residents told us that we were in Bgy. Palanit, San Isidro, Northern Samar – an area where numerous hold-ups and murders take place.  With the help of the residents, the policemen and army soldiers sent to help and guard us, and the mayor’s brother, we were able to find a hauler and a forwarder truck that would transport our van to Tacloban City, Leyte despite the fact that it was Christmas Eve, and a van we could rent to bring us to our town.  We were able to leave Samar at 7pm, and because of the terrible, terrible roads, we traveled at an average of 40-50 kph.  Consequently, when the clock struck 12, we were still struggling in Samar, nowhere near Leyte.  It was my first time to celebrate Christmas on the road.

    I wonder what the governors and congressmen of the Samar provinces are doing about their roads.  The Pan-Philippine highway was constructed to connect Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao through a continuous road, but alas, it is discontinued in Samar.  The car-shop in Tacloban City tells us that more than 50 cars were brought to their shop, just this Christmas season, all because of damages similar to ours.  Good roads are a characteristic of first-world countries, but how will our beloved Philippines achieve the efficiency and productivity it aspires for if there exists roads such as those in Samar?  Trade necessitates good roads; Samar and Leyte, for example, are agriculturally rich lands but how will the produce be transported to Manila and other places if the roads connecting the venues for retail remain in a decrepit state?  Tourism necessitates good roads; since we pushed through with touring the entirety of Leyte for the remaining duration of our vacation, I know for a fact that just like the Bicol region, the Visayas boasts of sights at par with those that I’ve seen abroad.  But how will these places be appreciated if they are made unreachable due to cruel and unfriendly thoroughfares?
    
Because of the bittersweet experiences and emotions I’ve been through, I will certainly never forget this year’s Christmas.  I’ve seen the grandeur of the places our country offers, alongside the inconvenience one has to endure to get there; I’ve been exposed to the intolerable fixers at ship ports, and robbery/murder-prone areas, alongside hospitable residents, and kind army men who never hesitated to help us in our time of need; I’ve experienced isolation and being so far away from my comfort zone in Manila, alongside meeting hitherto unknown relatives.  Indeed, this year’s Christmas will be one I’ll always remember.

I woke up this morning to the sound of my two younger brothers beating each other up in the next room.  The object of the conflict was simple: using the computer; the aggravating factors were even simpler: the older one’s assertion of superiority and the younger one’s cry for equality.  Because they are adolescents, it isn’t surprising to witness the use of force instead of rationality, and a fistfight instead of a discussion.

    But overly stupid fights like these are not only seen in the family setting.  In fact, the family is but a microcosm of society, of the world.  Numerous wars in mankind’s history have been caused by the assertion of superiority by the strong – military supremacy, economic competition, ideological prevalence – and the cry for equality by the weak.  And this is the result of envy, spite, revenge and other evil forms scattering far and wide in our world. 

    The existence of these evil things is an embodiment of the myth of Prometheus and Pandora.  In the story we see the curiosity of Pandora unleash a ‘multitude of plagues for man’s body and mind’ and thus resulted in the degradation of the world from a Golden age of truth and innocence to the Iron Age of ‘fraud and the wicked love of gain.’  But as stated in the myth, all the evil contents inside the jar, which Pandora opened, escaped except hope.  That is why, as it was then and as it is now, no matter how seemingly grave and discouraging our situation becomes, hope never really leaves us.  No hardship is too harsh for as long as we have hope.
    
    Oftentimes, this is even all that we need to keep going.

I have just recently gotten back together with the only guy I’ve been in a serious relationship with in the last 5 years.  There were big changes in our lives and our selves, which led to big fights, which in turn led to break-ups. There were flings after we’ve broken up before, but nothing more.  Now, we’re back together, and we’re taking it slow.  Now, more than ever, and after reading Scott Peck’s weird essay, I am convinced that I indeed love him – past the infatuation and honeymoon stage, past the dependency and possessiveness, past falling in love – just love, right in the thick of it. 

    In the past, there were lots of set-backs in our relationship.  One factor is that when we first got together, we were very young (high school).  He was a permanent part of my daily routine and as time passed on, the predictability has tolled upon its pros and cons.  Predictability offered the security that he would always be there.  But at the same time, it fostered monotony, and being young, I wanted to try new things, and wanted space from him, keeping in mind, that he would always be there…but he wasn’t and I don’t blame him.  I broke with him for stupid reasons.  I screwed it up.

    When we got back together towards the end of freshman year in college, we tried so hard to get things back to the way we were when we were happy in high school.  We tried to get the old “us” back – which was hard and downright impossible since we were already in college, were in different schools, were older, and simply not the same persons we were before.  This lack of predictability fostered the lack of security and we weren’t used to it.  The lack led to dependency, possessiveness, and frustration because we couldn’t achieve the ideals we had.  He was the one who gave up and broke it off this time.

    After a few months of silence, we started going out and spending a lot of time together again – but this time as “friends.”  During this “friends” era, a lot of things have happened.  There were traumatic experiences (hospitalizations, running over a person!), unforgettable experiences, forgettable experiences, fights, making up, and lots more, and these things turned our relationship into something deeper than it ever was before.  He is the one person that knows me inside out, and I am that to him as well.

    And now, we’re officially a couple again, taking take 3 in a serious boyfriend-girlfriend relationship that looks like it’ll grow and last.

    We’ve both made mistakes, and a lot more mistakes after those mistakes, and contrary to the belief of some of my friends who say that we should give up, I think that all it means is that we both still have a lot of room to grow.  I believe that mistakes and learning from them is a sign that love advances.  And when love advances, people should take second chances (and third chances too!) in order to promote that growth.  Love isn’t easy.  If it’s easy, then it’s effortless.  If it’s effortless, then it’s not love to begin with.  That’s my opinion.

    In a relationship, sometimes it feels like its heaven-sent one day, and then the next, you’re back in hell.  Sometimes it feels that it just gets more and more confusing everyday, like it’s going nowhere, and that you want to just walk away.  It’s always a mixture, a push and a pull, extremities fighting for the victory of the last stand.  But the thing is, I believe that what holds a relationship together is the will of both parties to hold it in, and make balance.  Love, ultimately, boils down to choice – both will and action – and the parties must exert utmost effort in keeping their end of the bargain.  Of course, sometimes, one would have to pull the string harder to reach balance because the other is having some difficulty.  Sometimes, one is compelled to exert more effort than the other.

    I hang up, he calls.  He gets mad, I apologize.  I screw up, he understands.  He becomes narrow-minded and stubborn, I become patient.  I walk out, he follows me.  

    Balance.

    And this time, we’re doing better with the balancing act. Maybe it’s because we’re older.  Maybe we’re more mature. I know there will be more fights, but then again, there’ll be more making up.  There’ll be more misunderstandings, and then more apologies.  There’ll be more mistakes, and more learning.  There’ll be more growth…and this time we’ll do it one step at a time.  This time, we’ll take it slow.  Maybe I’m being overly optimistic about this whole thing…I don’t know.  All I know is that I’m certain this time will be a lot better than the past.

“Welcome home,” the immigration officer said to me smiling as I presented to him my blue passport when I went to New York City last year to spend my semestral break.  That’s one of the privileges of being a dual citizen, I am exempted from the tough screening the people in the “Aliens” line get upon entering the United States.  As I waited for my friend who was of course taking much longer in that line, and who was unsurprisingly chosen for “random” inspection, I felt a surge of guilt towards my fellow Filipinos.  If not for a grandmother with American roots, I would have also been in the “Aliens” line with my friend, enduring the indirect discrimination and hassle (Filipinos get interviewed longer and always get chosen for random inspection of luggage) that comes along with being a Filipino.  But no, I escaped out of a mere technicality and though I’m happy and grateful for it, I can’t help feeling guilty too.
  
  Life is hard of a Filipino especially if one belongs to the lower class.  Here in his own country, he would probably roam the streets the whole day, enduring intense heat or heavy rain, just to sell one stick of cigarette, one cob of corn, one piece of mango. With over 70% of the population below the poverty line, most people don’t have any other option; they can only sell a little and can therefore only buy a little as well. The Philippines fosters a very small degree of retail and I know it’s not because Filipinos don’t have a big appetite. As Nick Joaquin puts it, the Filipino heritage is a heritage of smallness, operating on such a tiny scale and more often than not, the returns are never proportional to the effort; a Filipino labors so much and get so little in return.  And so he goes abroad in search of greener pastures.

    I am not part of that statistic and the case is very different for me.  Here in my country, life for me is very comfortable and this luxury, admittedly, is far from being proportional to the effort I exert in school or at home; I don’t work for what I have now yet I am enjoying life so much, sometimes living outside my means when I splurge on my credit card.  When I go abroad, it is not in search for greener pastures because my pastures here are as green as it could be, but for a vacation.  I am lucky to be born in a well-off family and I have escaped life’s harshness thanks to my parents.

    In the one month that I was in New York, my two great escapes dawned on me greatly and I felt I have to maximize my good fortune of being an American citizen and my being pretty well-off.  Most Filipinos would do anything to fix their papers for an opportunity to go abroad and earn more, and here I am with no problem with that.  Because of this, I was so tempted to study in New York especially when my cousins were convincing me that it was a good idea and Fordham University said they would credit my units in Ateneo.  I saw it as a new opportunity to be independent and to do something out of the Filipino heritage of smallness; studying abroad would not be operating on a tiny scale, in fact it would be a very, very big leap and challenge to prove my worth as a Filipino amongst other cultures.  And besides, the search for something new is not necessarily an attempt to escape something bad.  Sometimes, it is merely wanting something different from the norm.  In this case, the new thing should be something worthwhile for it to justify the effort of deviating from the status quo, which by itself isn’t so bad at all.  And at that time, living in New York seemed to be pretty worthwhile.

    Even when I told my mom that kids in the States were normally out of their parents’ house at age 18, she was reluctant about the whole idea, saying that I was too young for that and that she didn’t want to let go of me just yet.  And that’s one positive thing about the Filipino heritage: we really do have close family ties.  Yes, it’s true that we think small and do small and that because of that, we are impoverished relative to other nationalities, but at least we’re happy in the company of our family.  One article in Time Magazine I remember describes Filipinos as being “hungry but happy” and I laughed but realized it’s quite true.

    And so my New York game plan is postponed for now.  I’ll probably do it after college and get a masters degree there and that’s one thing to look forward to.  In fact, on the flight back to the Philippines, I was all smiles because of this.  “Mabuhay! Maligayang pagbabalik,” said the immigration officer to me smiling as I presented to him this time my green passport.  Yes indeed, it’s good to be back home…to my real home.

It was already the wee hours of the morning of April 3, and I was still up, chatting with friends on the Internet.  I don’t know why, but for some reason, a friend and I were talking about wakes and funerals.  We were going on about where we would want our wake to be, what song would be playing in the background, who we think would actually visit, who we think would deliver a eulogy for us.  It was a long conversation revolving around ourselves individually and how we wanted to be remembered, but in the end we came up with an agreed upon insight.  We agreed that we would be eternally touched and grateful if someone we least expect to speak, goes up the podium, reaches for the microphone, and delivers some kind words about us.  Wouldn’t it be wonderful to know that unknowingly, we have touched someone’s life?
   
     Right after I pressed the enter key to end that statement, my cell phone rang, and I got news that a high school batch mate of mine shot himself in the head just a couple of minutes ago.

    Words cannot express what I was feeling.  Shock, disbelief, bewilderment - all battling inside me.  It couldn’t be true, it just can’t.  It was my best friend who called me, and well, we’ve had a history of pulling pranks on each other, so even after she said it, I still left room for the possibility that it was not so.  But it was true.  Eddie was dead, and we all had to accept it however difficult it may be.

    And it was very difficult.

    Late into the morning, my best friend started spreading the news of Eddie’s death thru text.  They were close family friends, and that was the task designated to her.  It was a simple text informing the recipients of his passing, details of the wake, and a request for prayers for the family he left behind.  His mother was already a widow, his brother blamed himself totally because the gun that Eddie used was his. 

    Times are always hard when a family member dies, but given the circumstances, Eddie’s death made it infinitely harder.

    Eddie wasn’t the kind in high school who went up the stage during recognition to receive an academic award, wasn’t a jock, and was pretty inactive in extra-curricular activities.  He made a couple of imprudent decisions, took a vice or two, repeated junior year.  From what I hear from my best friend, he wasn’t really close to his family either.  He wasn’t perfect…just like each and every one of us.

    I didn’t even know Eddie that well.  He was just an acquaintance, an ex-boyfriend’s kabarkada in the old days, a family friend of my best friend, a familiar face I used to see everyday along the hallways of our high school.  I can’t explain it, but for some reason, I am greatly affected and bothered by his death.  Maybe it’s the manner by which he died, maybe it’s the mystery behind it (he didn’t leave a note), or maybe just the waste of life.

    He shouldn’t have died.  He shouldn’t have died.  He shouldn’t have died.  That’s what I think over and over again.  No one that young should die.  He has only lived a quarter of his life, not even reaching his prime.  He should be in college, doing what me and our other batchmates are doing: living life.     

    But life’s not fair.  We should deal with it with acceptance, not bitterness – a friend told me that, and she’s right.  Eddie’s dying wasn’t fair to his family, to his friends, and even to him, but there are things that are beyond our control and we should accept that.  As the priests say, “we should see death for what it really is: the end of poverty and the beginning of riches, the end of fear and the beginning of tranquility, the end of pain and the beginning of strength.”  About remembering Eddie: we should remember him not because of the list of his imperfections, but because of all the beautiful years he shared with the people around him.  He wasn’t the perfect student, but he was a thoughtful and caring friend.  He wasn’t really close to his family, but he loved them and they loved him greatly in return; closeness is a relative term anyway, while love, absolute.

    One last thing. Why was I up at past 2am last April 3?  Why was I chatting?  Why was that particular weird friend who asks weird questions online, too?  Why were we talking about funerals of all the other weird things to talk about?  Why did my best friend call the second after I pressed the enter key?  It’s weird, really weird, but somehow, at the same time, equally enlightening.  Now, exactly 2 weeks after his death, I suddenly have an epiphany…

    Because we were talking about funerals, my friend and I came up with our insight.  And because of that insight, I’m writing this essay.  I probably am the most unexpected person to speak about him, but somehow, I feel I owe this to Eddie.

When I want to do some thinking, I always find myself driving. Driving for miles and miles with no clear set destination. Driving really fast, driving really slow, depending on my mood, depending on circumstance. And no matter where my aimless wandering begins, I always end up in the Fort. It’s not a place of grandeur; its not even home. So why do I wind up there? This is why: there are places we all come back to – sentimental places – because they helped make who we are now. And even if we’re all grown up, feigning maturity and wisdom, we will always come back, like a child in search of comfort. 

    I was a senior in high school when the Gonuts Donuts in the Fort, its pioneer branch, first opened. I just got my own car then, and being always eager to drive, I'd often take my friends to get some donuts before going back to school, 5 minutes away. The staff then, very grateful that we frequented their isolated place, always asked us to tell everyone about their haven of soft luscious donuts. It seems so long ago, especially now seeing different branches of Gonuts Donuts, and always full of people.

    Its also the place where I practiced driving. Those were the days when encountering an intersection seemed like the end of the world. I’d shiver with fear and pray that it wouldnt be my last day. Seriously. But now? I’m willing to drive all the way to tagaytay on any given day, driving really really REALLY fast, with time acting as pressure and intersections...what intersections? 

    Its also the place I meet my closest friends at. Since all of my friends inconveniently (for me) live in the south, Makati's the middle ground, and our regular place to rendezvous.  And since I hate Makati, as in Makati CBD per se with all its one-ways, and no-left-turns, and no u-turns, and what-not, we always meet up in the Fort. In Starbucks. In UCC. Wherever. So that we could catch up on things, catch up on what’s happening in our lives, lives that at one point in time were so inseparable, and now have inevitably drifted apart.  But come to think of it...Fort's not even Makati in truth is it? It’s in Taguig. Not many people recognize that but yeah, the Forts part of Taguig not Makati. But so much about being politically accurate, right? It looks extremely Makati-ish anyway.

    It’s also the place an ex boyfriend and I always hung out in. It was the place where we had most of our dates in. The place where we had the fondest times. I can associate every nick and corner there with some memory of him.  And ironically, it’s also the place where we argued; whenever there’s a fight coming up, we would park at a parking lot in the Fort and there we would argue, sometimes shout at each other, and when things get really bad, that was where we would part ways.

    What a place.

    A venue for fostering friendship. A place that elevates status from "just friends" to "more than friends". And also, sadly, the host to "more than friends" becoming "just friends" again.

    There are places we go back to. At times we take it for granted, to our detriment. At times we simply forget about it, turning our backs on it at the risk of self-contempt. But people don’t go on like that for long because there would really come a time when we would NEED to go back to this place. We would come back not to endure nostalgia, not to relive a moment passed, not to attempt to recover or repair old issues, good heavens no. We come back to sanctify memory. 

     And well, sometimes remembering does us a lot of good. Especially when our mind's a mess and we’re driving around, trying to fix it.

Many people agree with Nick Joaquin, many people don’t.  I know he’s not entirely accurate with everything he says and writes, but we have to admit that he has a point – a big point.  I am a frustrated writer so I’m very appreciative of good books and essays, and I love Nick Joaquin’s choice of words.  In fact, as I was going around the Metropolitan museum, looking at the rows and rows of pottery and thinking to myself, “So what the hell is so special about these pots?  God, they’re ugly,” his words were ringing in my head – “…we feel equal to materials that yield but evade the challenge of materials that resist…” – and right you are, Mr. Nick.

    Culture is always a touchy subject for us Filipinos because we cannot, as a people, agree on what defines “Filipino culture.”  Some say the Spaniards stole it when they came, some say the Spaniards improved it, and some say we didn’t have a culture prior to Spain’s coming and that Spanish influence and how we adapted to it is our culture.  But oh well, regardless of what is correct, more importantly, the essential thing is the now; What is our edge over other cultures now?  What makes us truly Filipino now?  That we  had, still have, and will always have the ability to make pots?  Surely not.  Figuratively and literally, are we not capable of making something bigger and nicer?  Are we just being humble?  I think not.  And as Mr. Joaquin says, “Are we not confusing timidity for humility and making a virtue of what may be the worst of our vices?”  Now the ugly clay pots our forefathers made sit in a museum located in our Central Bank.  Does these things really merit national treasure security?  Oh what low standards we have, then.

     I may seem harsh, unpatriotic even, maybe the pots have a deeper story behind  them, maybe they are indeed worth a lot, but for me (an average 19 year old college student), they’re just ugly old pots.  And that says a lot about our culture.  In my opinion, beauty and size matter in the measure of a culture’s greatness, and if an ordinary 19 year old student like me (and most of classmates I’m sure) doesn’t find a certain legacy of our own country pretty, then there must be a problem.  All Italians find Michaelangelo’s David impressive, all Russians say “wow” to Tolstoy’s Anna Karenina.  But Filipinos regarding pots?  We don’t say wow, most of us say “Ngyek ano ba yan?”  I know we have other things to be proud of like paintings, and the gold collection, but I just can’t seem to get over the pots.

    On the other hand, in the National Museum, I was slightly impressed with the balanghay (not sure of spelling, but it’s the big boat on display).  When I saw it, I thought to myself, “Nice boat, I wonder what our ship looks like.”  Then I realized that there was no ship because that already was the ship.  In our pre-colonial times, while the Spaniards, Portugese, Dutch, and English were busy with their big ships roaming around the world in search of the unknown, we were busy with our balanghays going from island to island just within our small archipelago, sometimes to trade and sometimes to fight with the other kingdoms (although there are some accounts of a few Filipinos on balanghays going to China I think, but that’s insignificant).  And so Nick Joaquin strikes again, we could have been a great society if there had not been a “fatal aversion to synthesis.”  That’s just how we were then and how we still are now: we love small because we don’t think we can handle anything big.  Anything big intimidates us like hell and unfortunately, we’re too scared to even try.

    And that’s the bottom line: we’re scared.  Why didn’t we progress after mastering the art of making pots?  Why didn’t we move on to glass or stone?  Why didn’t we build bigger ships?  Why didn’t we venture beyond the sea?  Because we were scared.  We deceive ourselves by thinking it’s impossible and so we stick within our comfortable zone, thereby making us stagnant.  Then in the long run, as the population swells (there are other factors besides population of course) and our problems multiply, given that our effort remains small, we find ourselves incapable of doing even the smallest of things.
 
   It sucks to think that we were that way before.  But what’s suckier is the thought that until now, we are still that way.  We are mediocrity personified; for us mediocrity is bliss.

I concede, as I type the first few words of my essay on melancholy – sheer melancholy.  Every night it somehow manages to creep deep inside my consciousness, completely paralyzing all other thoughts except those that are of the same nature.  It takes full control of my mind, and gives birth to thoughts and emotions that are its kin like paranoia, insecurity, hopelessness. 

 Rhetorical questions flood in and I am caught in awe at all the ideas that arise because of this, and the fact that no matter how hard I try, I can never answer them.  I can only formulate hunches, mere guesses, but ultimately, I will never know for sure.  There is no escape from this torture and the only way out is admitting defeat; its victory is assured even before the challenge is posed.  And every night, though its strategy of attack varies, I always concede.  I am dumbstruck, incapable of moving, of fighting.  It somehow comforts me to know I fought a good fight, but in the end I always offer my concession.  And now once again, melancholy has visited me and has assailed me, hitting me where I am most weak – the heart.  And now once again, I admit my defeat.  Now once again, I concede.

It certainly is a mystery why we’re together.  We are oh so different from each other, always at opposite ends of the river, and for the longest time, no one has ever dared cross the bridge.  I get exhausted from always standing on the edge, shouting so loud in the hope that the message will come across, and somehow reach him.  And maybe this [exhaustion] is the cause of melancholy’s nightly visits.  I am sad because of the state we are in, being on opposite ends.  Why can’t we just be on the same side?  Or maybe we could meet up in the bridge, the middle ground.  Or maybe he can just cross over.  I’m hoping he’ll accept the fact that I am on side A, and I intend to stay there, while he being on side B will cross over.  Fat chance.  We both know what we want; the problem is we don’t want the same things.  Bummer.  Someone has to give in.

And now, I’ve decided to give in; last night’s melancholy was the worst.  I am not the kind of person who thinks long term.  I live for the present; I appreciate every moment.  Planning ahead is a waste of time because it eats precious minutes or sometimes hours that should instead be spent happily for the present.  But that’s just my bullshit.  My real reason for not thinking long term is that it scares me.  Yes, it scares the hell out of me.  What if things won’t turn out the way I expect them to?  What if I thought wrong?  What if the ending does not occur in line with the happy ending I imagined?  What if I fuck up?  And what if the only reason why things don’t end up happily is because I fuck up?  And the litany goes on.

I’m perfectly fine with the idea that I only see him every Sunday.  Is the feeling actually normal?  I think not.  I can’t smoke when I’m with him.  God, I know I sound so selfish and stupid defending a vice and escaping my boyfriend at the same time.  But hear me out, it’s not just that.  I feel so choked, so limited, so incarcerated when I’m with him.  
“Wear your seatbelt.”
“Don’t drive too fast.”
“You can’t smoke when you’re with me.”
“You curse too much.”

And the litany goes on…but despite the fact that I’m a person who does everything I want when possible, I concede and follow him.  Partly it’s because I don’t want to put up a fight, partly because I’m too lazy to refuse, and partly because he’s actually right.  Any person watching us from afar would readily say that he’s got the upper hand.  He’s right, no doubt about that.
But then it’s fun to be wrong.

It’s fun to drive without a seatbelt; those things are so uncomfortable.  It’s fun to drive fast; living life on the fast lane, baby.  It’s fun to smoke; you can see the stress rising up to heaven in the form of smoke.  It’s fun to curse; putang ina.

And yet, I still concede.  Tonight, with melancholy as the singular catalyst, I’ve reached the height of my concession.  I don’t know if I’m experiencing a quarter life crisis like Chip, but tonight, all of a sudden, I’ve decided to give in.

Yes being wrong is fun while it lasts, but afterwards, the stupidity of it all sinks in and creates a splash of melancholy.  Woooosh.  And then I start to fashion ideas in my mind – ideas that completely paralyze all other thoughts except that of its kin.
We rarely agree.
We always fight.
Is this healthy?
Is this relationship actually going anywhere?
I wonder how long it will last...
Oh shit, I’m thinking of the long run.  Help, help, I’m scared.

But then screw the fear.  Yes almighty fear, you win and I lose.  Now as I sigh my sigh of resignation, I concede.  The only thing missing is a pat on my back.  Yes, I lose but I’m not one who wallows in defeat.  Yes I lose, and I’m doing it gloriously.  If he goes with us to Batangas, I swear I won’t smoke.  I won’t even drink too much.  And it’s actually okay.  It’ll just be one long Sunday, one long day in incarceration, but not being less happy than that when I’m free. Yes, being happy in jail is possible.  Isn’t it ironic?  I may be a hard headed, narrow-minded person, but I do know how to value things that matter most.  And he matters most, no doubt about that.

I don’t like Batman.  He is not cool, not superhero material.  I mean, what’s he got to brag about?  Superman was from the planet Krypton, Spiderman got bit by a mysterious spider, the Hulk was a screwed-up chemical guinea pig (right?), the Fantastic Four got exposed to radiation.  But Bruce Wayne?  He’s nothing but a rich kid with a quasi-good cause.  He was out for revenge, helping others was just an added bonus.

     That’s just me though.

    Others actually find him appealing.  Most people like the fact that he is perfectly human---no special traits whatsoever---but still capable of accomplishing extraordinary feats.  Some like his costume, the mystery an all black outfit emanates maybe, bad fashion sense if you ask me.  Capes are so unsafe for super heroes; they get caught in buildings, posts and what-not.  Some people like the dark side he has, adds a dash of spice to his character, and that’s what we are going to ponder upon.

     Bruce Wayne did not have a happy concrete operational stage (approximately from 7-11 years old - Piaget).  In other words, he had a sucky childhood.  One time, he fell into a deep well that was full of…who would have guessed…bats.  He was stuck there for quite a long time until his daddy came to rescue him.  He was very close to his dad by the way.  Then, not long after, his parents were robbed of and shot right in front of him.  These two occurrences had a deep impact on his personality to say in the least.  Obviously, these were traumatic experiences for him as proved in what will happen to him in the future.  But we’ll get to that later.  Another effect on him was the biased classification of people he resorted to.  In the concrete operation stage, classification skills are present, but abstract thinking is not yet developed.  Ergo, thinking becomes operational, logical thinking without intuitive thought.  In line with this, well using my amateur skills in psychoanalysis, I think young Bruce impulsively classified criminals unjustly; his schema became “all criminals are bad…they killed my parents…they should die too.”  Being an only child, he was really alone, with only Alfred as his companion.  This led him to detach himself from reality in his formal operational stage (approx. 11 to 15 yrs old - Piaget).  He then repressed his grief and concentrated more on “solving” his problem in a really idealistic manner, which is typical in this stage of life.  

      In a nutshell, Bruce Wayne had everything anyone could wish for, and because of the untimely demise of his parents, all that came crashing down. But life went on and he faced the world, carrying the grief on his shoulders at the same time.  Corollary to this, he developed an identity-versus-identity confusion. He was probably thinking, “I’m not the same person I was before and will never be again, so what am I going to be now?”  Big dilemma that should have been.  And since Bruce, whether in the comics or the movies, was never really known to have long-time girlfriends or best friends (save Alfred), I assume he developed an intimacy-versus-isolation disorder as well.  He doesn’t want to be close to anybody anymore because he fears losing them; he fears getting hurt so much again.  Lastly, in my opinion, he also acquired a renewed (since this already occurred at age 1-3) sense of autonomy.  With the death of his parents, he was endowed with a new sense of independence and moreover, a new purpose in life.  And since he was pretty rich and pretty intelligent, he quickly put this sense and purpose into action, concretizing it in a name that will be forever remembered: Batman...(tene nene nene nene)... Batman. . .

    And so it was...just as he planned it would be.  During the day, we see Bruce Wayne---Gotham’s most eligible bachelor: rich, famous, smart, what more could you ask for, girls?---walking through the metropolis head-high accomplishing all that is expected of him and nothing more.  But at night, he is Batman---secretive, heroic, but with a hidden agenda---roaming through Gotham’s streets accomplishing all he expects of himself, and so much more.  He beats up all kinds of villains from petty thieves to rapists to murderers.  He doesn’t hesitate to kill them if circumstance necessitates, and more often that not, it does.  It would be tedious to psychoanalyze all the antagonists in Batman’s life so now, we only focus on one.  The villain of inquiry for us today, ladies and gentlemen, is someone named the Joker.

    Joker’s real name prior to assuming that stupid alias is Jack Napier.  He was a member of the mafia and did all kinds of bad stuff from stealing to murder.  He became one of Batman’s victims of no mercy when Batman let him fall into this pit of chemicals which permanently damaged him physically, emotionally, and mentally.  The joker was psychotic...that was harsh, sorry.  Well, from a psychodynamic springboard, we see the Freudian concepts of id, ego, and super ego coming into play.  Joker was so caught up with his id, not giving a damn whether or not his pleasure-seeking instincts were in conflict with society’s rules, or if they were even moral.  Nah, all that mattered to him was that his “needs” were met.  Batman, in contrast, did not let his id rule.  He attained a balance with these structures.  He took into account his id – instinctual call to punish all criminals, his ego – the demands of reality to return to his Bruce Wayne identity as a normal citizen, and his superego – his conscience...although that part wasn’t so evident because of the countless people he killed.  

    Another essential concept to describe Batman and the Joker is Alfred Adler’s Individual Psychology.  This is kinda ironic because Adler was against Freud’s adherence to the power of the unconscious mind.  But oh well, both of them are motivated by their goals and purposes in life.  The indelible line is drawn by their different ways of living up these goals and purposes.  Batman grew up with everything good around him.  Everything just shattered when his parents died.  So as a result, it is only apt that he chose the path of good as well.  In contrast, Joker grew up with everything bad around him.  All he saw was crime and violence even before he became the Joker.  Here we see the impact of the influences a person has in his or her life.  The things and people around a person, although seemingly insignificant at times, are indeed great factors for who and what that person will eventually become.

    That in a nutshell is Joker and Batman in comparison.

    As a final note, let’s tackle the climax between hero and villain, the battle of good vs evil.  In one of the encounters of Batman and Joker, the latter uttered, “Have you ever danced with the devil in the pale moonlight?”  Joker said he liked saying this line to his victims before they died because it had a nice “ring” to it.  Well it indeed affected Batman.  Apparently, this line triggered Batman to retrieve the flashbulb memory of his parents dying in front of him with none other than Joker, then Jack Napier, as the murderer.  Flashbulb memories are memories stored with a great deal of emotion in them.  They are usually very personal and are almost always more accurately retrieved than other memories.  And even at a time long after the actual occurrence, all that’s needed is something, anything at all, that will turn on the bulb so to speak.  Joker’s supposedly goodbye statement triggered Bruce Wayne to remember that dreadful day and it affected his decision-making immensely.

    In the final stretch of the movie, we see Joker cajoling Batman, challenging him to a duel of popularity.  Joker wanted to be the “king” of Gotham and it ate him alive that Batman was rivaling him in popularity.  Anyway, Batman in his normal state of mind, wouldn’t even mind the childish challenge.  But because of the flashback memory and the fact that Vicky Vale (his current object of affection) was hostage, all feelings of hatred and the want for revenge resurfaced.  Batman’s id has managed to dominate his mind and his instinctive drift drove him to accept.  In the end, Joker died.  Good has once again prevailed.

    So I guess Batman isn’t such a bad superhero after all.  He wasn’t altruistic, was what is ideal for all heroes, but I guess it’s okay.  The egoism is justified with Gotham being free of the Joker forever.  So happy ending?  Nah...I don’t think so.  There are many more villains, others more threatening than the Joker.  And Bruce Wayne will never have peace unless all those bastards are put to an end.  The revenge was attained, but the hatred still remains... 

    Batman...(tene nene nene nene)...Batman!
